title: Trump to Rally Ahead of North Carolina Election Seen as 2020 Bellwether
text:
President Trump is holding a rally Monday on behalf of a North Carolina congressional candidate as he goes all-in on a special election both parties see as a referendum on the man in the White House and a bellwether for his 2020 chances.

The president won the Charlotte-based Ninth Congressional District by 12 points in 2016, and Republicans have held the seat in the House of Representatives for decades.

But Democrat Dan McCready came within 900 votes of winning last year, a reflection of Democratic energy in the midterm elections that saw the party flip 43 House seats and shifting political dynamics in the fast-growing Charlotte suburbs. Tuesday’s do-over election was called in February after the state election board found evidence of absentee-ballot fraud on behalf of the then-GOP candidate, pastor Mark Harris.

Mr. McCready, a 36-year-old solar entrepreneur, is taking another run at the seat, this time facing Republican Dan Bishop, a 55-year-old state senator who won a 10-way primary last spring after Mr. Harris decided not to participate in the redo. Polls show a dead heat between Mr. McCready and Mr. Bishop.

Tuesday’s vote is a test of how voters, particularly suburbanites who make up much of the district, view Mr. Trump as the 2020 campaign kicks into gear, people from both political parties said in interviews.

“That is the top issue for most of the people we talk to,” said Jim Blaine, a consultant for Mr. Bishop. “It’s a test of the enthusiasm of both parties.”

Mr. Bishop has campaigned almost exclusively on his allegiance to Mr. Trump, making the president’s endorsement a centerpiece in his ads and sharing the stage with Mr. Trump earlier this summer at a rally in Greenville, N.C., when the crowd chanted “Send her back,” about a member of Congress and U.S. citizen originally from Somalia.

“If Bishop wins, it shows the health and continued strength of the Trump coalition,” said Mr. Blaine, describing the coalition as rural and populist voters in the eastern stretches of the district and core suburban Republicans.

If Mr. Bishop loses, he said, it will be a sign that a winning Democratic strategy in a red or swing state is to run as a centrist and at a distance from the progressive wing of the national party.

Carolyn Eberly, founder of the grass-roots group Indivisible NC District 9, also said the race was about Mr. Trump. She said her group was formed to “resist the current administration’s agenda.”

She said she has worn a McCready shirt as she knocked on doors for 10 out of the past 11 days in the GOP strongholds of southern Mecklenburg County and Union County southeast of Charlotte. “There’s so much energy out there,” she said. “There are still people that are not on board, but there are others who see me and are honking and cheering.”

Mr. McCready rarely mentions the president by name on the stump, saying instead that people want a change in tone and a move from divisive rhetoric. He has campaigned as a moderate and a Marine Corps veteran, pledging to put country over party.

Mr. Trump on Monday told reporters he thought the race was “getting less close.” Earlier, he tweeted his support for Mr. Bishop, saying, “We need him badly in Washington! His opponent is a far left Sanctuary Cities supporter.”

Mr. McCready tweeted a response, saying, “Actually, there’s one person in this race who has kept this country secure. I signed up after 9/11 to defend us in the Marines and fight the terrorists.”

The Ninth District is concentrated in Charlotte’s southern suburbs, which account for about 60% of the vote total. The district stretches three hours’ drive east of Charlotte through several rural counties and includes part of the military town of Fayetteville, where Mr. Trump will hold Monday’s rally.

Mr. McCready held his own rally with veterans in a downtown park in Fayetteville Monday, saying that in his platoon in the Iraq war, no one cared whether you were Republican or Democrat.

“We put our country first,“ he said. ”That’s what this country’s all about and that’s what they’ve forgotten up in Washington."

Mr. Trump is the reason the district is in play, according to David Wasserman of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. Republicans are desperate to avoid a setback in a state critical to their 2020 prospects for holding the White House and taking back the House.

“They badly need a morale boost at the moment,” Mr. Wasserman said, after a dozen GOP House members announced their retirement in the past year. “This is their turf, they have to prove that they can hold their own ground.”

Outside groups have spent a near-record amount for a single special election, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Groups like the national parties’ congressional committees have spent $6.8 million to boost the Republican, and about $3.9 million to help the Democrat.

Both campaigns predict turnout to be relatively low and the result to come down to hundreds of votes, as it did in 2018.

Democrats outpaced Republicans in the first weeks of early voting, but Republicans have narrowed the gap and also tend to outvote Democrats on Election Day, said Donald Bryson, president of the conservative, Raleigh-based Civitas Institute.

Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com
